references: The notations used in this paper are listed in TableÂ I.

We discuss SlimFL and global model aggregation in further detail. SlimFL is denoted by the symbols shown in TableÂ I. AlgorithmÂ 4 describes the fundamental SlimFL operations. The network consists of Kğ¾K devices that are linked through wireless connections to a parameter server. Each device uses SC whilst communicating with the server, whereas the server uses SD. To be more descriptive, kğ‘˜k-th device has a local dataset Zkâˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ’Z^{k}\in\bm{Z} and an SNN parameter Î¸ksuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta^{k} with two width configurations. Across devices, the global data ğ’ğ’\bm{Z} may be IID or non-IID. Each SNN Î¸ksuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta^{k} is subdivided into an LH Î¸kâŠ™Îdirect-productsuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜Î\theta^{k}\odot\Xi and a RH segment Î¸kâŠ™Îâˆ’1direct-productsuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜superscriptÎ1\theta^{k}\odot\Xi^{-1}, where Î=Î1ÎsubscriptÎ1\Xi=\Xi_{1} and Îâˆ’1=Î2âˆ’Î1superscriptÎ1subscriptÎ2subscriptÎ1\Xi^{-1}=\Xi_{2}-\Xi_{1}.
Superposition training is used to train the kğ‘˜k-th local device (lines 4â€“9), which is expressed as (3).
The local device transmits to the server the SC-encoded local model Î¸ksuperscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta^{k}.
Each local device transmits two messages (i.e., LH and RH segments), each with a distinct transmission power P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} relative to P1â‰«P2much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{1}\gg P_{2}.
The uniform random variable Ïâˆˆ[0,1]ğœŒ01\rho\in[0,1] is sampled for user kğ‘˜k as ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k}. The sampled ÏksubscriptğœŒğ‘˜\rho_{k} and the decoding success probability p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}, p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2} are used as a criterion for whether LH and RH are successfully decoded. It is identical to calculate (9).
In accordance with (9), after reception, the server can successively decode using SD and obtain: (i) a 0.5x model if Ï‡â‰¥c/(P1/uâ€²âˆ’P2)ğœ’ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒ1superscriptğ‘¢â€²subscriptğ‘ƒ2\chi\geq c/(P_{1}/u^{\prime}-P_{2}) (lines 15â€“17) is satisfied; (ii) 1.01.01.0x model if the channel fading gain satisfies Ï‡â‰¥maxâ¡{c/(P1/uâ€²âˆ’P2),c/(P2/uâ€²)}ğœ’ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒ1superscriptğ‘¢â€²subscriptğ‘ƒ2ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒ2superscriptğ‘¢â€²\chi\geq\max\{c/(P_{1}/u^{\prime}-P_{2}),c/(P_{2}/u^{\prime})\} (lines 18â€“20); and (iii) otherwise it obtains no model. As a result, the RH segments from ğ–¥ğ–¥\mathsf{F} of devices and the LH segments from ğ–§âˆªğ–¥ğ–§ğ–¥\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F} of devices are combined by the server.

To show the effectiveness of the proposed SlimFL, we consider a classification task with the Fashion MNIST (FMNIST) image datasetÂ [37]. The impact of other datasets such as the CIFAR-10 and MNIST datasets will be discussed in VI-E. The dataset is randomly sharded and distributed across devices. FollowingÂ [38], the non-IIDness of the data distribution is modeled using a Dirichlet distribution with its concentration parameter Î±âˆˆ{0.1,1.0,10}ğ›¼0.11.010\alpha\in\{0.1,1.0,10\}, where the higher Î±ğ›¼\alpha implies the more non-IID data distribution as illustrated in FigÂ 2. For numerical experiments, we adopt the light model of slimmable MobileNet, i.e., UL-MobileNet111This paper utilizes Ultra-Light MobileNet (UL-MobileNet) under the consideration of the limited computing capacity of local.It follows MobileNet architectureÂ [39]. UL-MobileNet consists of five convolution layers activated by the ReLU6 function, average pooling function, and linear layer.. We consider a single communication round consisting of a pair of uplink and downlink transmissions for each local training iteration. The communication channels over different devices are orthogonal in both uplink and downlink. The Rayleigh fading gain Ï‡ğœ’\chi for each channel realization follows an exponential distribution Ï‡âˆ¼Expâ€‹(1)similar-toğœ’Exp1\chi\sim\textsf{Exp}(1)Â [28]. The corresponding communication and neural network hyperparameters are summarized in TableÂ II.
We adopt Vanilla FL as a comparison technique. Vanilla FL is widely used FL technique (i.e., FedAvg) with a fixed-width SNN model without leveraging SC nor SD. We consider three Vanilla FL schemes as listed follows:

We design additional simulations to verify SlimFL works in more realistic channel models (e.g., Rician fadingÂ [30] and Two-wave with diffuse power fading (TWDP)Â [41]).
In indoor wireless communication, Rician fading is superior than Rayleigh fading. In addition, TWDP is used in air, space or maritime wireless communication, where the channel fading is worse than RayleighÂ [42]. We simulate Rician fading with Kğ¾K-factor 3.53.53.5, where the fading follows Rician distributions Ï‡âˆ¼Riceâ€‹(0.5577,0.2106)similar-toğœ’Rice0.55770.2106\chi\sim\mathrm{Rice}(0.5577,0.2106). (K,Î”)ğ¾Î”(K,\Delta)-factor of TWDP fading is set to (3.5,0.1)3.50.1(3.5,0.1). All communication settings without fading effect are identical to TableÂ II. Fig.Â 11 is the result of the simulation. As shown in Fig.Â 11, the top-1 accuracy is found to be high in the order of Rayleigh fading, TWDP fading, and Rician fading channel models. SlimFL-1.0x always outperforms SlimFL-0.5x. Thus, SlimFL performs well in a variety of channel models.

Thus far, we have evaluated SlimFLâ€™s performance after training using 1,00010001,000 epochs. We estimate the energy consumption till convergence in this section. Numerical convergence in training is defined as the point at which the standard deviation (std) of test accuracy falls below a predefined threshold and the lowest test accuracy exceeds the average test accuracy in 100100100 consecutive rounds. To assess model convergence, we establish the reference values for the mean Î¼ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿subscriptğœ‡ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 80%percent8080\% and Ïƒğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿subscriptğœğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 7.25%percent7.257.25\%, respectively. Convergence occurs when the average Top-1 accuracy for 100100100 consecutive epochs is greater than Î¼ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿subscriptğœ‡ğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} and the average std is less than Ïƒğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿subscriptğœğ–±ğ–¾ğ–¿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}}.
With this convergence criterion, TableÂ VI compares the overall energy costs of SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.5x until convergence, based on the communication and processing energy costs per round in TableÂ IV. As shown in TableÂ VI, harsh non-IIDness (Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1) with poor channel conditions makes FL convergence hard. SlimFL, on average, produces a 3.63.63.6x reduction in total computing costs and a 2.92.92.9x reduction in total communication costs until their convergences. In addition, Fig.Â 3 shows the energy efficiency results corresponding to accuracy. As shown in Fig.Â 3(a), SlimFL requires only the 32.63%percent32.6332.63\% of Vanilla FL-1.5xâ€™s total communication cost for model convergence. Similarly, the computing cost for SlimFL is the 44.37%percent44.3744.37\% of Vanilla FL-1.5xâ€™s as shown in Fig.Â 3(b). This increased energy efficiency is according to SlimFLâ€™s faster convergence even in non-IID and/or bad channel circumstances caused by SC and SD.

Between ten devices and a server, the total quantity of data communicated is 205.8205.8205.8MBytes for SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.0x, and 102.9102.9102.9MBytes for Vanilla FL-0.5x under ideal channel conditions (i.e., always successful decoding). We investigate the efficiency of communication resources in both good and bad channel conditions to validate the effectiveness of SC and SD.
The experimental result for this subsection is presented in TableÂ V, which shows that SlimFL delivers up to 3.52%percent3.523.52\% fewer dropped bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x when SC and SD are being used.
SlimFL enjoys the benefits mentioned above while consuming only half of the transmission power and bandwidth compared to Vanilla FL-1.5x, as presented in TableÂ V, corroborating its communication efficiency. Because a part of the transmission power of SlimFL is allocated to 0.5x models, SlimFL decodes less than 1.0x model bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x. In return, SlimFL receives not only 1.0x models but also 0.5x models simultaneously. The additional received 0.5x models coincide with the LH parts of the 1.0x models, which improve the accuracy and convergence speed of both 0.5x and 1.0x models.

references: SlimFL and Vanilla FL both achieve high accuracy when channel conditions are good, as shown in Fig.Â 5 and TableÂ VII. When the channel condition deteriorates from good to poor, however, as shown in Fig.Â 5(c,f) and TableÂ VII, Vanilla FL1.0xâ€™s maximum accuracy at Î±=10ğ›¼10\alpha=10 declines from 868686 to 828282 percent. SlimFL-1.0x, on the other hand, retains its maximum accuracy of 878787 percent at Î±=10ğ›¼10\alpha=10 in both good and bad channel conditions. Additionally, at Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, SlimFL-1.0x outperforms Vanilla FL-1.0x by 18%percent1818\% in terms of top-1 accuracy, despite the fact that Vanilla FL-1.0x consumes more communication and computing resources. Additionally, as the channel condition degrades, the std of Vanilla FL-1.0xâ€™s top-1 accuracy increases by up to 59%percent5959\%, while SlimFLâ€™s std increases by just 31%percent3131\%. These findings show SlimFLâ€™s resistance to poor channels conditions, as well as its resistance to non-IID data distributions (low Î±ğ›¼\alpha) and communication efficiency.

SlimFL-0.5x has a stable convergence under Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 condition, as indicated in Fig.Â 5(dâ€“f) and TableÂ VII In poor channel conditions and with the non-IID distribution (Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1), Vanilla FL-0.5x and Vanilla FL-1.0x display the std of 8.38.38.3 and 9.29.29.2. On the other hand, SlimFL-0.5x and SlimFL-1.0x both demonstrate the std of 2.42.42.4 and 2.92.92.9 with top-1 accuracy. This propensity persists even when Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1, Î±=10ğ›¼10\alpha=10 are prevalent. SlimFL-1.0x and SlimFL-0.5x have a smaller coefficient of variation than Vanilla FL-1.0x and Vanilla FL-0.5x. This accentuates SlimFLâ€™s robustness to non-IID data on poor channels.

To verify the impact on heterogeneous computing capacities of devices, we investigate six-width configurations (e.g., 1/6x, 2/6x, â‹¯â‹¯\cdots, and 6/6x).
First, we train SNNs with the default settings of SlimFL (Î±=10ğ›¼10\alpha=10, K=10ğ¾10K=10, Ïƒ2=âˆ’30â€‹dBsuperscriptğœ230dB\sigma^{2}=-30\text{dB}). Then, we measure top-1 accuracy and calculate FLOPS.
Its specification is presented in Table VIII.
Second, we investigate the dynamic width adaptation to the device, which has a time-varying theoretical peak performance of the CPU, denoted as RpeaksubscriptRpeak\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}} (MFLOPS). We set Rpeakâˆˆ[20,230]subscriptRpeak20230\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}}\in[20,230] (MFLOPS).
Lastly, we calculate the number of image processing per second (IPS) by the following metric:
